Well the thing is the ipad air and ipad mini retina have virtually the same performance - ipad air is 4% faster. Plus they display at the same resolution, despite the smaller screen, so ipad mini just has a sweet like 348 dpi resolution, better than the air by quite a bit. The ipad mini is infinitely more portable - it can fit in a small purse or a coat pocket. The even get the same battery life. The more condensed screen is easier to type on with thumbs and less fatiguing on the eyes in terms of travel. I could only see someone preferring an air for old eyes or if watching movies with others is a big priority.

I am writing this as an upgraded view not as a first time iPad buyer. i got the 64GB version but i did also post this review on the 16 and 32 versions because the 64gb version was nit listed for sale here until just recently. i bought the black, i had the white. i went black because as beautiful as the white is i found myself looking at the bezile often. the bright white distracted me from the screen sometimes. the bezel fades out of view when black and i find myself seeing more of what is on the screen.

the retina display is a huge upgrade. i have corrective lenses and need 1.25 reading glasses. reading all text on the retina is worth the upgrade for me. while i do not have an iPad to compare the color gamut i can say that i think the colors are fine. the display is a worthwhile upgrade consideration. as much of an improvement the screen is the processor is an even bigger improvement. i use to see load time of a game called Field Runner2 HD (there is a free version too) of 40 seconds or so, the new mini loads twice as fast . i wish i took a video of the two side by side before i sent my old one to a friend. it was amazing how much faster the new iPad loads games. i posted a video of game load time on another Mini review page, sorry i no longer have it to post here.

i would like to say the iPad mini should have had the fingerprint scanner and all Apple products are overdue for built in wireless charging. still this is a really nice product and i am glad i spent the money on the upgrade.

I bought this for my wife. She liked my iPad, and wanted one that she could bring to school to take notes with instead of bringing around her bulkier laptop, along with a ton of books (doctoral students get a lot of things to carry). I have the iPad Air 2, but I couldn't find my particular model in a price that I could afford at that time. When I went on Amazon, I found the Mini 2 at a very good price. I decided to buy it for her, and it came here a few days later. She's very pleased with it so far, though typing is a bit of a challenge even with a case with a keyboard. The difference in size makes typing naturally difficult, and is something I should've put more consideration into, especially because I personally have a hard time typing on my Air 2 - I tried typing on hers, and my fingers created a beautiful word salad (I have quite big hands).

For games she loves it, and she can access a lot of her textbooks very easily. That was a great benefit of buying the iPad - now she can rent a lot of her very expensive textbooks (the ones she doesn't want to keep) in a digital format and just tote along the tablet instead of a massive hardcover. Reduced her weight in her bag, and the tears in our eyes when we open our bank accounts after we purchased our books for the next semester. The screen is great - both of ours have the Retina display, and while I originally thought it was a massive gimmick and refused to shell out more money for it on my first MacBook Pro (Mid-2012), my newest MacBook (Mid-2016) definitely was going to have it. Also, I love the night mode, and use it on my tablet, Mac, and iPhone, as it really does help my eyes at night.

For reference, the iPad Mini 2 I purchased was the WIFI  32gb in silver.

32GB's are not enough in this day and age, and Apple didn't make this tablet with expandable storage. It's ok for pre-school up to and including 2nd grade children who simply want to play games and delete them and download new ones. It doesn't really need the Face Time pre-installed on it though, considering the age level of child that it's suitable for. This amount of memory however is definitely not enough for a child older than that and certainly not adequate in any way shape or form for an adult. The operating system is nice, user friendly and functions very well, but the tablet itself is extremely over-priced for what you are getting. If Apple had given the buyer an option of adding an SD card of at least 128GB or more, then the tablet would have been adequate for adults as well as children and worth the buying price. A huge oversight on their part.

First off and full disclosure...I'm a long time Apple hater.  I only bought the Mini 2 because I was having trouble with my Nvidia Shield K1 tablet when using it as a flight display for the DJI Mavic Pro.  I really don't know how Apple "is all that" to so many users as there products are supposedly easy to set up and operate.  In fact, the set up did go fairly smoothly but of course you have to have an iTunes account to get set up which is a drag.  Why the assumption I want music?  So once it was setup then I needed just TWO apps and both were Free.  Finding the App Store on iTunes is like looking for Where's Waldo?  Turns out Apple on iTunes doesn't really care about apps as they have hidden the link down below the fold, so to speak with a little ink.  Unlike Google that puts all these thinks together in a logical format.

For a FREE app there was a "Get It" click then a "Install" click.  Why would I want to get it and not install it?  Then there was a financial click.  No card need because this was FREE.  Then there was some sort of continue click.  Were there more clicks? I lost track.  Eventually, it did load.  I repeated the same process for the other FREE app.  Apparently, the Apple gods took mercy on my poor Android soul and then offered that I could now skip many of these steps in the future for FREE apps, if I wanted this option.  I did.

Function in flight.  It works better then the K1.  The K1 was great until either an OS upgrade or DJI Go 4 upgraded, not sure but the display would disconnect in flight.  Not critical to flight but still annoying.  The Mini 2 does not cut out, yeah.  However, it does drag. Dragging means as you pan with the onboard camera, the Mini 2 displayed picture stops panning (freezes might be a better description) for a second or two.  Not smooth or cool at all.  After about 15 minutes of flight time (or on the second flight after a battery) is when the screen begins to drag.  I don't know if this means the 2 is overheating or what.  Maybe I should have bought a Mini 4?

As a Apple hater, I do admit that the screen does look pretty dang good.(when it is not dragging).  BTW, it was sold to me as brand new and it did come in what appeared to be a new sealed Apple box with the original associated gadgets (ear phones and power adapter/charger).

2 stars off because the display drags after only about 15 minutes of use and the software download experience is a stinker.

Bought this tablet computer for my wife, who uses it on a daily basis for Facebook and Amazon Prime and PBS videos. She loves it, which surprised me because normally she isn't very patient with tech products like this. She reports it's been pretty easy to use.  We've also used it a couple of times to do Facetime video chats with relatives who have Apple products like an iPad or iPhone.  Works very well.

I think I know my tablets: I previously owned the original iPad and the Kindle Fire, and now have an iPad Air, and my wife has an iPad Mini 4. So I have high standards and an easy way to compare them.

I purchased the Mini 2 for only one reason: I fly a DJI drone that needs a phone or tablet to see where you're flying. My phone's screen was too small, my full sized iPad Air was too heavy, and my wife didn't want me to "borrow" her Mini 4.  I thought an 8" tablet would be perfect, and I was right. The Mini 2's screen is beautiful and bright with Retina Resolution; with a small sunshade, it's perfect even in bright sunlight. The contrast is terrific and I can finally see even the finest details.  The processor is fast enough to handle the considerable workload and complexity of DJI Go software.  I was very happy about all that...but none of that surprised me.

What did surprise me is how well the Mini 2 performs as a general use tablet. The screen is very slightly less vivid than the Mini 4, but equal or better than almost all other tablets, and has the same high resolution. The sound is about the same. The processor is snappy-- fast enough for everything (except possibly high end gaming). The  sensitive and quick. And it's so small and light that it can be used for hours without tiring  your arms. Apple has upgraded all the 2s to 32gb, so storage is ample.  (Don't be suckered into buying a refurbished model that's only 16gb.) At the Black Friday price I paid (not on Amazon) it has to be the bargain of the century.

Bottom line: Even though  the Mini 2 originally was released two years ago,  it is still a great tablet.

From the Retina display and the A7 processor chip compared to the original iPad minis A5 chip to the super easy finger glide screen and everything in between, this is a phenomenal product. I had the first iPad min for......way too long, so I started shopping for a new one. I always stay within the Apple product universe for tablets and phones (just not Mac's they confuse and scare me though they are quite amazing) and I love the size of the mini series, it's just perfect for a casual user like me. I was bouncing back and forth between the mini 2, 3 and 4 and I'm super happy and satisfied I ended up with the mini 2. The mini 3 is well, pretty pointless.....it has a finger scanner and.......and............a finger scanner........oh and I think it also comes in gold but.......to me it looks like buttcheeks. That's it otherwise is the exact same thing as the mini 2, in fact I looked on Apples website and they dint even offer the mini 3, openly at least it's not in the comparison list for all the iPad models. So after realizing the mini 3 was just a re-skin of mini 2, my choice came down between the mini 2 and 4. I'll admit the 4 was the better choice obviously, if you have that kind of money to just throw at a tablet, but mini 2 won because well it's cheaper for one and it alone is a tremendously colossal upgrade from the original mini. Going from the first mini to mini 2 is like going from a caveman stone wheel Flintstones car, to a NASA Space Rocket Ship. Yes it's just that good of an upgrade, and I image the jump from mini 2 to 4 is just time travel. If you have the money to shell out for the mini 4 by all means go for it, but if you're looking to save a lot of money and still get a mind blowing product then I'd suggest going with the iPad mini 2 but that's just me. Personally to me saving money is earning money and I'm passed the phase in my life where I absolutely need the latest and greatest piece of technology to survive. Going with something that may not be the very best but is still a great or even, in this case, a phenomenal product is just a more logical and smart way of thinking about things and you'll be happier overall because you still have change left over to buy something else or will give you an extra boost in saving up to get what you want later on. So my consensus is, iPad mini 2..........I love you.............original iPad mini...........I think we should see other people.....

My issue is the Apple software and oppressive security and the management of that security.  I own an Apple iPad mini and it still worked fine, until there was a glitch in one of the applications that caused the software security feature of the iPad mini to request the Apple userID and password.  Like most people, I rarely have the need to use the password and I got it wrong enough times that it locked my account.

Here is where it got weird My Apple userID was an old email address that is no longer valid.  I could only get one of the security questions right (did not write them down when I first filled out the security stuff they put me through).  I contacted the Apple technical support and was told that because I could only get one (1) of the security questions right and it is required to get 2 out of 3 correct, there was nothing that they could do and my iPad Mini would never function again.  NOTHING THAT THEY COULD DO! and now I have an Apple paper-weight on my desk, because I could not remember enough information to satisfy their policies.  It is fair to say that the situation was caused by my negligence in not being able to comply with the Apple policies, but to turn my iPad into a paperweight is NOT equitable or justifiable punishment.  They could fix this, IF THEY WANTED TO!   Apple has chosen to NOT help.

My advice- purchases anything other than an Apple product.  While I understand the need for security and privacy, the Apple Company has placed the strict, zero-tolerance, administration of their policies over the needs of their customers and over common sense!  They have left me NO recourse in solving my problem, so I am making it my mission to let others know of pitfalls of dealing with an Orwellian like company.  Run away from this company and spend your money with anyone else!

Lightning fast delivery speed from the seller, and item arrived well-packaged and in factory sealed box. However ... It was really hard to tell from the listing whether this was a new unit complete with factory warranty (one year). When I called Amazon Customer Service (best customer service in the WORLD), I was assured that it was indeed a new unit with an Apple factory warranty in place. When I received the iPad mini 2, the first thing I did was register it on Apple's website, and it was there that I discovered that not only was one month of the warranty already used up, but that my telephone assistance for the unit had expired ..... So - what I was told was kind of true, but not completely true. It was less expensive than on Apple's own website, but not by much. Was the savings enough to warrant having lost a month of warranty, and telephone assistance? Can't answer that, really. Just hope I don't have any issues that would require telephone assistance! Other than that, I bought this unit to be able to access my son's iCloud, filled with pictures of the new baby, and also to be able to FaceTime the baby when she's old enough (very soon). It's the only Apple product we now own, apart from our iPods from years and years ago.

This Ipad is great. I have found it to be the perfect size for me, and it's very portable. It's got all the power and ability as the larger ones, just in a smaller size.

If you are reading this and you're not sure if you should get it because there are other, cheaper tablets out there (there are tons), then hear me out. I have wanted an Ipad for the longest time, but never bought one because I didn't have the money for it. When I did get the money for it, I was just going to buy another cheap tablet (I've had to buy several because cheap tablets don't last very long), but I decided to go for it. If you have the money, and you want an Ipad, then get an Ipad. This thing does not disappoint (for what I use it for).

I basically use this tablet for everything, except for games, and primarily reading. For that purpose, this tablet does wonderful. The screen is very clear; if you are upgrading from a cheaper tablet, then the screen will probably blow your mind, and if you're transitioning from another, high-quality tablet, then its probably just gonna be "meh". The battery life on it is very good. I charged this to 100%, unplugged it, and watched an hour and  a half long movie. When the movie was over, the ipad was at 94%. Anddd, with the split screen option and the ability to watch the movie while you work, I was watching the movie, checking facebook, emailing people, and all sorts of things; needless to say, the processor and battery on this thing is impressive.

I gave this four stars for two primary reasons - the wifi connectivity could be better (the the new kindle fire hd has an impressive dual-band whatcha ma call its), and I have found the page turn animation quite annoying while reading and I can't figure out how to turn it off.

If you want this ipad, and have the money, then get it, you aren't going to be disappointed. If you are looking for a tablet to watch a lot of movies on, this will do well, but you could also look at the kindle fire's which have an impressive screen quality for a low price. If you want web surfing, this does well. If you want a gaming tablet, I suggest you do more research (there are some by asus and other brands that have some impressive processors on board). And finally, for those of you who are photographers, the camera is alright, not the best thing ever; however, the photo editing apps are quite cool and may come in handy. All in all, this is a great tablet that will more than likely work for your needs.

I am a professional video maker; I get paid to make marketing videos for several local businesses in the Daytona Beach area. I needed this gadget because it's rated to work best with another gadget I needed. Being a Windows/Android guy, now I can tell you why:

Cons:
-It feels like it's going to snap in my hands. Nice and smooth? Yes. Sturdy? No way. I'm not going to test that theory.
-No micro port. I mean, cmon.
-I always felt that Android's add-supported apps were annoying, but a necessary evil. The app store's "Freemium" content is downright PTSD inducing and had me daydreaming about this thing meeting my friend Pietro Beretta.
-A 5 megapixel camera? How groundbreaking. I know this thing came out in 2013 or so, but my old Samsung Galaxy S3 has an 8 megapixel camera, and it's a year older.
-The marketing of SIRI is way better than the actual use of it.

Pros:
-People think it, and by extension, you, are "cool", even though neither of you really are.
-Battery life seems to be very good.
-The camera has some cool features.

In conclusion, if you're a hipster who wants to look like you're doing something important, even though you don't even have your own wifi, this is the gadget for you. If you need to get some actual work done, get a Windows tablet. If you just need to communicate, navigate and update while you're mobile, get an Android tablet.

I really really love the iPad mini 2. BUT, you need to be aware that it is just like other Apple products. It doesn't support flash, which I have already had an issue with when trying to play sample audio files on a simple Spanish website. I really would like to be able to do something so stupidly simple, yet Apple, despite its tremendous resources, cannot find the willpower to fix this issue for the many iPad owners in the world. It's such an amazing product, yet has these tiny flaws that will eat a new owner alive. Furthermore, along this subject, you will often be groping in the dark for at least a little while to figure out how to accomplish certain tasks on the iPad. This actually doesn't mean that you cannot do almost everything, just that Apple does it differently. Enough time has passed that Apple has figured out how to incorporate MOST of the key features that ought to be included in any standard table. But there ARE holes in the system. Overall, I would say that you should be fine getting one, but be aware that tricky workarounds make it difficult to go to certain websites and use them properly. Codecademy apparently is available for use using a different browser than Safari, but you cannot use a keyboard for the time being. This is terribly frustrating, but not a dealbreaker. Overall, just be aware that iPads are better-suited as ENTERTAINMENT devices, not necessarily always for productivity purposes.

iPad Mini 2, Fantastic Product!

This product is perfect for anyone who is interested in something that could function like a laptop but is also lightweight and easy to carry around. Many people who would be satisfied with this product is children, students, and even professionals in the workforce.  I am a college student who constantly uses a laptop on a daily basis for school. After a couple of years I wanted something smaller to take notes and do homework on so I bought the iPad mini 2. I would have to honestly say that buying the iPad mini 2 was one if the best things I have done.

Advantages
 It is so lightweight and easy to carry it around in a backpack and even a purse. I measured the success on the product based on if it functions similarly to a laptop.
 It has full internet access and you can even download Microsoft office for free on it.
 It is very simple to take notes on and it allows you to physically draw on the notes, unlike laptops.
 It has a picture and video camera on both side of the iPad and a full touch screen keyboard.

Disadvantages
 The only issue I had was choosing what memory size to get because Apple products have limited memory. I ended up choosing the 32g and it has been more than enough memory for all of my documents. You can also use iCloud to maximize your memory for the iPad.

If you are looking for something smaller and simpler than a laptop, this product is perfect for you! I was completely satisfied with the product I bought.

Wonderful and Awful. First lets look at hardware. On the good side, the screen is beautiful and the device feels good to use (when it works). On the bad side there is no way to upgrade memory, no SD card, no USB port, no way to replace the battery and it only will charge with apple (expensive) chargers (Seriously!!).

On the software side the iPad is OK if all you want to do is social media, youtube, email and web browsing. Don't be fooled into thinking that you can be productive and creative with this device. If you wan't that get a laptop. Apple has locked down the device and limited it so much that it is just a toy. This was very disappointing to me because the device has potential to be so much more. iOS was designed for phones and so the iPad feels more like a big smartphone than a small computer.

Getting data onto and off of the iPad or getting apps to communicate with each other is a nightmare. Each app stores its own data and, unless the app has been explicitly programmed to export, there is no way to get at the data it creates. Each export feature works differently. There is no standardization between apps. Each different app requires half an hour of research and googling to discover how to export its data.

Getting data onto the iPad must be done through iTunes and "Synched" onto the iPad. If you have two people in the house with different iOS devices then each person NEEDS their own computer. A single computer CANNOT be shared by two iOS devices. I bought a bunch of apps for my daughter's iPod. It was made obsolete by apple so she switched to an Android device. I would like to transfer those apps to my iPad. Can't be done. Those apps are locked away until my daughter gets herself another Apple device.

I have also had two multi-hour troubleshooting sessions where my iPad did not behave properly in the past six months. When iOS 8.0 came out my WIFI broke until apple released an update (8.1). In the latest case my iPad would not Update Apps and would not download new Apps for two weeks. I tried many suggestions on internet forums including factory reset but nothing worked. Then it suddenly started working again. Given the price premium I expected a trouble free experience. My PC laptop is much more reliable and hassle free.

I had expected that the iPad would be a small ultra-portable computer that I would be able to do real work on and be creative with. Instead it feels like a camera that can email and browse the web and do social media.
Exceeded my expectations, takes the place of my bulky laptop.

My first piece of advice...Be very aware of from whom you are buying this tablet. I purchased NEW from my local BestBUY. My friend recently purchased from the AMAZON site but the tablet came from a reseller. She thought she was getting a brand new tablet,well it was not new but a refurbished tablet!

Refurbished can be OK if that's what you paid for but if you bought new you should get NEW !

If you want a refurbished model ONLY buy from the apple store website as those are truly certified refurbished models with new casings, new batteries and 1 year warranties.

Now for my review:

I purchased my Ipad mini 2 to replace my aging Kindle HDX 7 inch. I also researched and tried ( at BESTBUY STORE ) the Samsung s 8.4 tablet.  The Ipad mini 2 is basically the same tablet as the mini 3 except for the finger print reader.

I felt the Samsung and the Kindle had BETTER screens than the iPad mini 2 . However EVERYTHING else about the iPad mini 2  is better.

* It seems faster,has few crashes and hang ups compared to my Kindle HDX. Stays connected to WIFI better than KINDLE HDX
* More intuitive to set up and operate
* Has way more available apps than KINDLE HDX or Samsung
* Better overall build quality
* Battery life is about 10 hours with moderate usage ( web surfing, game playing, downloading and listening to audio books )

I have broken the screen twice on a KINDLE HDX . The charging port failed on my second one just after the warranty was over. I am done with Kindles!

I read many reviews for the Samsung tablets and they seem to have a short life too.

I have an old IPOD Touch 4 that's still going strong. I feel the extra money for an apple product is worth it over the long haul.

Its your call but your spending a lot of money for any of these tablets. Do your research and buy carefully!

So when I was in the market for an iPad mini for my son, getting a large-capacity iPad mini 2 made a lot more sense than purchasing a comparable 3. The processor is the same, the super sharp retina display is the same, the housing is the same, and the camera's the same.

For my iPhone the fingerprint sensor is very convenient for one-handed quick unlock. For the iPad I see less benefit for the fingerprint unlock, so it isn't worth an extra $100 for just this purpose.

So I called Amazon and they said, to either cancel and return item or keep it the way it is. I was hesitant because I didn't know if I would have an issue with the AT&T chip even though I turned off the cell data in settings. Nevertheless, a month later, no issues have arose with the iPad asking me to insert an AT&T cell chip. I am happily using my iPad mini 2 with retina. It is a great product. Size is perfect. I love reading my books on iBooks and editing my pictures as well as my videos with the apps from the App Store. I suggest buying this iPad mini as oppose to buying the new one on the market. You will be happy.

Gorgeous product. I love the idea to take the iPad and shrink it down to 7 inches. That's how I kind of envisioned when tablets were conceived in the first place. A product that one can hold comfortably with a single hand for extended periods of time, even when laying down. Its sleek, elegant, and in a way, looks even more premium than the larger version due to its size.

The screen is solid, not quite as sharp as a Macbook, Apple has managed to add on a retina screen for the 7.9 incher, so everything looks fantastic. The iPad mini can last me nearly 10 hours on a single charge; I usually keep the brightness on a medium to semi-generous level. The apps pull up without much of a delay and the internet connection is usually solid as long as my service isn't faltering.

The camera is very good, and videos look competent, though I opt to watch those on my laptop. If you have a student, especially one who demands a tablet along with a laptop (the product I'm reviewing is my father's), the iPad mini is ideal, but somewhat pricey.

I had the original iPad when it first came out, and ended up returning it because for whatever reason, I just didn't like it at all. I decided to give iPads another chance, and I'm so glad I chose this particular model. The mini size is PERFECT, especially for people who will be using this device recreationally and occasionally for professional tasks, because I personally don't think this is for people who are expecting it to completely replace their desktop or standard computers. I found it to be the perfect size for FaceTime, reading books, and to fit inside my purses/backpack. The display is incredible (I am also using a ballistic glass cover by TechArmor) and I have stable wifi connection at any place with public wifi. It never glitches or disconnects like I experience with my phone. I have not experienced any problems with the battery life -- it lasts me all day, and I would say I use it just as much as I use my phone. The cameras aren't incredible, but they're pretty good quality compared to the other tablets on the market. I also recommend the Yippee iPad cases here on Amazon -- way less expensive and every bit as good as the Apple SmartCovers.

I LOVE my iPad mini.  I upgraded from the original iPad 1 and so the differences of these two devices are truly night and day.
I remember when I first got my iPad 1, thinking it was so lightweight and portable and now it just seems so oversized and bulky.  However, that original iPad is still kicking!  If it weren't for the lack of updates and preventing from using a lot of the current apps AND the fact that I had a strip where I had messed up the pixels I probably owuld have been content to carry on with the original iPad.

The iPad mini is just truly a breath of fresh air.  I had contemplated getting a bigger screen, but really found that I didn't feel I needed a huge screen to perform the tasks I needed on a daily basis.  The iPad mini is truly so much easier to slide in your purse and use on the go.  The weight of this device is almost like carrying air.  It's just so easy and trust me I have this device in my hands almost every second of everyday.  It literally is glued to me at all times.

The camera isn't the BEST, but it's better than you'll find on similar devices like the Fire.  It's much clearer and crisper than what you would expect a tablet to have.

I have the 16 GB and honestly, it was fine for awhile, however with how often iOS updates I would recommend never purchasing below 32 GB.  I had a 32 GB on my original iPad and still managed to run out of space (Don't even think of having movies stored on your devices each movie is at least 1 GB and that seriously is a huge chunk of storage space).

The screen is just so bright and clear.  I didn't think it could get better than the original ipad and man, technology just keeps making things better and better and better.  It's amazing the thigns you can see when you zoom in with your camera because of the high definition of the screen.

I love the multitasking on the ipad.  Just everything about the iPad is top notch to me.  I purchased a Samsung Galaxy 3 7" tablet last year and was so disappointed at how slow it was and how it just didn't perform well and was always crashing.

The iPad mini has crashed more often than I experienced in the early days of the iPad original, I'm not really sure why that is...  However, iOS is still a much more stable system than androids are.  I am so much more confident of my information being safe and secure than I am on any other operating system.  I just don't seem to have the same issues with iOS devices as I do with android or windows.

If you are wanting a tablet to use as your primary internet device, than I definitely recommend iOS and the iPads because they just truly peform better than anything out there.  Fire tablets are nice, but you are so limited as to what you can do on them and they just don't even come close to being on the same playing field as the iPad.

The ONE thing that I am not so crazy about is the charging cable that iPads use now.  I never had any issues with my cables on the iPad Original, the bigger charger just seemed to be more stable than the lightening one is.  I've gone through about 7 cords this year.  I don't know what the deal is with them.

It's a apple product so you know it's good but also the hardware storage memory is pretty low for todays age.. 16gb... So if you like downloading a lot of songs, videos, books and photos onto your iPad this model isn't for you. You should go for a 32gb but a 64gb to be really safe.

I write this review to hopefully clear up some confusion and concerns some of you may have.  This has nothing to do with how wonderful the device is, but rather with its network capabilities.  I wanted a mini  that would work on T-Mobile's network.  But in looking at most of the ones for sale, I found that the best priced iPads were for use on AT & T's network.  I didn't want AT & T but did want the cheap price.

I did a lot of research and was pretty sure that all that would be necessary was to replace the AT & T SIM card with one from T-Mobile.  Apparently the iPad's come unlocked from Apple even though they have a specific carrier's card in them from the factory.  So I gambled a little and bought one.  It came in the factory sealed box, so I knew it had never been messed with.

After it arrived I went down to the T-Mobile store to get my new SIM card and sign up for data service...and to make sure that the iPad  would indeed work.  IT WORKED JUST FINE!!  So if you're on the fence about buying an iPad for use on different networks, it will work with these two carriers for sure.  If you want use it on a different network, then do your homework.  From what I found, Sprint could be a problem

The iPad Mini seems to work as advertised so far.  However, obtaining Apple Care for this item has been a challenge.  According to the local Apple store employees, this item is not a U.S. market item (I am in the U.S.), but instead is manufactured for an Asian (Japanese? Chinese?) market. The local Apple store refused to sell Apple Care coverage for it.  They suggested calling Apple to obtain Apple Care, although they believed I would not succeed.  On the first two calls, the Apple representatives repeated what the Apple Store had told us; that the mini was made for foreign markets and could only be supported by Apple Care in that country.  On the third call, the representative sold me Apple Care and was certain the iPad mini is now covered.  I hope this is actually true.  Both the Apple employees in the store and at the call center asserted that Amazon is not an authorized Apple retailer and I should have expected problems based on that fact.  I would suggest a different source for an iPad mini.

Right after I bought this I found an upgraded iPad mini for $100 less.  Very annoying!

*** Why last year's Mini 2 is better than this year's Mini 3 ***

If you're thinking about buying an iPad Mini, you should strongly consider buying last year's model (the 2013 iPad Mini 2, formerly called iPad Mini with Retina Display) instead of the iPad Mini 3 that came out in Fall 2014.

They are almost identical: EXACT same processor, EXACT same display, EXACT same battery life, EXACT same hardware and dimensions, and they run all the same apps EQUALLY well. The only thing you get with a 2014 Mini 3 that was not on the 2013 Mini 2 is the fingerprint sensor (and a new color option: white front with gold back).

This fingerprint sensor is the same one that's on the iPhone 5S and later models. It has limited usefulness on the iPad; it's more useful on phones, since more and more transactions will be done using phones instead of actual credit cards.

So, if the Mini 3 and the Mini 2 are virtually identical, why buy the 2? Because it's cheaper. Apple still sells the 2 for $100 less than a comparably configured 3. But you can save even more than $100 if you shop around, because many retailers are clearancing their inventory of last year's Mini 2. Two weeks ago, I found a Mini 2 with cellular and 64gb at B.B. for $150 less than a comparably configured Mini 3. I bought two--one for myself and one for a family member for Christmas. Unless you really want the fingerprint sensor or the new white/gold color combo, skip the Mini 3 and save yourself $100 or more by purchasing a Mini 2 instead.

*** iPad Mini compared to iPad Air ***

I bought an iPad Air when it came out in Fall 2013 and love it. It's extremely fast and the thin/light form factor is amazing, especially compared to earlier full-sized iPads. I know the 2014 iPad Air 2 is even better in some ways: a bit thinner, a faster processor, better cameras, and a new display that according to iLounge is slightly improved. But the 2013 iPad Air is so great that this is the first time I've not felt compelled to upgrade.

The iPad Mini 2 (formerly called "iPad Mini with Retina Display") came out last year about the same time as the iPad Air. Unlike the original iPad Mini from 2012, the 2013 Mini 2 is not a crippled iPad; it is virtually as powerful as the 2013 Air. It's essentially a 2013 iPad Air in a smaller package.

While the Air is amazingly thin and light for a 10" tablet, the Mini 2 is noticeably smaller and lighter, which makes it easier to hold in one hand for long periods of time and also much easier to travel with. There are times when the Air's larger screen is important--for example if I'm reading a textbook or a large-format magazine on the device, or editing a giant Excel spreadsheet. But most of the time, I'm equally happy with the Mini's 8" Retina display. The Mini 2 runs processor-intensive games and apps virtually as well as the Air, which is to say very well indeed.

*** iPad Mini compared to Android and Amazon tablets ***

It's true, you can get a 7" or 8" tablet for less money than an iPad Mini. Amazon's own 7" Kindle Fire HDX is very good and much less expensive, as are some Android tablets.

A good Android tablet can do most everything an iPad can do, or even more. While each operating system has its loyal fans, in fact Android and iOS are both very good and, at this point, very mature operating systems with a large catalog of apps. Android OS is much more customizable than Apple's iOS, which is important to many Android fans.

I kind of don't recommend Amazon's own Fire tablets. They are essentially Android tablets with some of the Android features stripped away in order to keep Amazon content in front of the customer. If that doesn't bother you, Amazon Fire tables are very good and affordable, so they are worth your consideration.

I am fortunate that I can afford to spend more to get the device I really want. And to me, it's worth paying more for Apple devices. I prefer iOS to Android and I like the hardware Apple uses and the build quality of iPads. But others prefer Android devices and I can't tell you my opinion is more valid than theirs.

If you decide to buy an iPad, you almost certainly will be happy with your purchase. iPads have a very high owner satisfaction rate and a very low defect rate. Apple customer service is absolutely excellent. The hardware and software are great. The only remaining decision you have is: which iPad?

For me, the iPad Mini 2 is the best choice for the reasons I gave above. It's very powerful and fast, the Retina display is great, the 8" size is light and super convenient, and best of all it's much cheaper than the new Mini 3 despite being virtually the same.

I probably have a very unique perspective when it comes to electronic devices. First, I'm a major geek/nerd who has loved to learn about new things since I could hold an encyclopedia and reach a computer mouse. Secondly, I support technology for a living so I really hate fixing and/or configuring things for hours on end after getting home when I've supposedly left all that behind for the day. and thirdly, as a product reviewer I'm constantly seeing new devices and technologies and evaluating them to see if they are truly useful or just more junk. In truth though, in my deepest heart of hearts... I am...a GAMER.

I have been gaming on the go off-and-on since I got a SEGA Game Gear. Since then I've tried a Nintendo DS, a PSP, and naturally, an iPod Touch and then iPhone. I'm here to say...if you like to game on the go with touch screen interface and a huge screen you have GOT to get one of these!

Not Papa Bear or Baby Bear Sized, but Juuuuust Riiiiiiight...

Let's face it. While the new iPhones have nice big screens the previous iPhones and iPod Touches were just too dang small if you wanted to play games on the go (especially if like me your eyes aren't so great). I looked at the iPad, and quickly determined that sucker is just too dang large to haul around and use at home (I'll save it for when I'm a senior citizen). But this device...this is perfect. The screen is crisp and clear with excellent contrast and color definition. It's small enough that blowing up iPod/iPhones games to full screen won't make your eyes bleed, and large enough to really do high-budget games justice.

Thin as a stick, powerful as a locomotive

My last iDevice was/is an iPhone 4. It's performance is dreadful all-around. Interface is sluggish, boot time is slow, games take forever to load (I could go on). This device is solid, amazingly thin and light, and INCREDIBLY fast compared to that phone. Infinity Blade III loads in seconds, not in a minute, and looks even better than it did before. The sound is better than my iPhone. The boot time is faster. The interface is amazingly fast and fluid. The wi-fi connection is easily 5 times faster than it was on my iPhones and it doesn't lose its signal. I'm in love, I'm in love!

Business as Usual

All the business/finance apps that I had on my iPhone are available on this device, they just work better because they have been redesigned for the larger screen. And since the on-screen keyboard is much larger, it's much easier to put in passwords correctly. More information is displayed onscreen at once in mail, and apps like MINT and Amazon are much easier to use because you can view more information at once rather than constantly hitting the back button.

The name of the Game is the Game

Seriously, I got this device primarily to use as a portable game system? Yes I did. And it was a rather unselfish thing to do. You see, I like to unwind after a long day of work by playing some Hearthstone, checking one or two game Websites, and catching up on my email/buying a few small items on Amazon. For the longest time, I've been doing this on my desktop while my wife chills watching Steaming TV and playing with her laptop/tablet. No more! Now, I can finally sit NEXT to my wife and play Hearthstone while sitting close enough to get my wife a hug between turns! THAT'S the real reason I got this device. When you need to play a good game (and take care of a few after-hours business things) and still be sociable this is the answer.

As for the games? I get crazy looks from some people when they see what I'm playing on this device. While everyone else is playing Angry Birds, I'm playing the Infinity Blade Trilogy, Dragon's Lair Trilogy, Dodonpachi, Espgaluda, and of course Hearthstone. These are games with absolutely amazing graphics and gameplay, real showcases for what gaming can be like on this device. And I'm just getting started. I've got a 64GB device with iOS 8 installed so I'll be buying lots for shoot-em-ups, Strategy Games, and board/card games in the future. I still have 50GB of space left, and once I start Cloud-syncing my writing projects to my wife's Macbook, my Windows 7 Desktop, and this device, I'll be able to proof-read and edit the same projects from everywhere.

In conclusion

Previous generations may have been low-res, low-capacity, slow, and expensive, but that's a thing of the past. This sucker is lightning fast, high-res, high-capacity and ready to play. I got mine for $350.00 and for a planned 10 year investment that's a steal. Now is the time for doubters and haters to give Apple Devices another try. If you would like to make your electronic evenings more casual (and dare I say it, magical?) you pretty much can't go wrong with this device. 5 stars. High praise for an Apple Device coming from me (I gave the iPhone 4 one star).

First off, the OS uses up a big chunk of the memory right off the bat.  If you load a few apps, a few songs, a few photos, you will find you have almost none.  They tell you that's fine, because things are stored in the Cloud, but if you're offline...
Most importantly, however, you should know that this device is the least user-friendly thing I've ever encountered, and I've worked with a variety of computers for more than 30 years.  It's 'mindset' is so unlike a computer that everything seems counterintuitive.  I found the coordination between my iMac and the iPad to be very cumbersome.  You have to have updated your computer to Yosemite and your iTunes to version 12.  My iMac is less than 3 years old, but if yours is pre-2012, you will not be able to use Hand-off or Airdrop, 2 of their touted means of sharing.  If you don't read the manual, you're lost; luckily, you can download it (using up more memory).  For the past three months I've been on the phone to tech support more times than I can count; sometimes the person knows the answers, sometimes not, and occasionally they'll just tell you something that's just not true.
Yes, it's small, and yes, many things work well.  I bought it to travel, though, and the maps program is a joke, and so far I haven't found another that works well enough to use if you don't have an expensive cellular plan.  If I'd known, I'd have bought the 32GB or better yet a small laptop.

I will review the pros and cons of getting a cellular iPad model
Pros:
1. It works everywhere in your country and where there is no wifi available
2: most wifi networks detected are password secured so cellular is the way to go
3. Great for traveling around the country and other places
4. Gives you more online flexibility.

Cons:
1. Monthly data fee depending on how much you use(but it might be worth it though)
2. More expensive than wifi only models
3. If you buy directly from a carrier store it might be locked to that carrier and unlocking can be a difficult process, so when you want to travel depends if you have roaming available and how much roaming will cost you.( roaming tends to be expensive depending on the carrier)

All in all a wifi only iPad might be a safer option if you feel you don't need a cellular data plan.

I am an Apple fan from way back and I was very happy with this iPad before "upgrading" it to IOS 8 and then a few days later to IOS 8.02. The iPad was fast, responsive and had a beautiful display. I am normally a Kindle user but purchased this iPad mainly for work applications because of the size. The 7 inch Kindles were a little too small and the 8.9 was a little too large to carry in my purse when traveling. This iPad was just the right size. I have an iPhone so the operating system was familiar.

I like the sleek size and easy set-up for email and other apps which is the case across the Apple platform. The battery power is decent and I can use the iPad off and on throughout the day and recharge at night. It was easy to find covers and accessories because it is a popular device. I pretty much liked everything about it prior to the IOS 8 upgrade. It suddenly became a LOT slower when using it on a Wifi network with speeds that are typically in the 80 - 100 Mbps download range. Now it frequently hangs up after beginning to load a page and will not go further. It often gives a message that it cannot connect to the server. When I access the same page alongside  it in my Kindle HD, the pages load instantly without any issue. I have been comparing the two tablets for a few days and even this older Kindle leaves the iPad in the dust. I've tried various fixes from the Apple support site with no resolution to this problem. The only thing that seems to help us to turn off the iPad and restart, or sometimes putting it to sleep and restarting helps.  The new IOS has some nice features such as the new keyboard but that doesn't make up for the unresponsiveness.

I have decided not to update my iPhone to this new OS until the problems are resolved. Checking on different forums, I see that there are many other unhappy Apple users. Actually, this may be the push I need to look at other types of phones since my 2 year contract is up.

Reason for upgrading: Old tablet showed signs of its age, glitchy touch screen, sporadic battery life, and often needed reboots.

My tablet Use: Web Browsing, Gaming, Remote Control, and eBooks.

To keep things simple, Ive broken my review into 4 categories, and Ill review around them.

Setup / Ease of Use:
The mini comes fully charged out of the box.
AppleID registration was simple.
Was up n running in just a half-hour.

Speed
Applications open instantly
Scrolling is jitter-free
Websites display instantly, just like a desktop computer.

Size
Perfect all around for a 7.9 Inch Tablet.

Vs Nexus 7 1st Gen
Keeping in mind that the 1st Gen 7 is 2 years old and runs on 4-year old hardware  the experience is night and day (as expected.) The upgrade is definitely worth the money, but the ONLY downside is purchasing the same apps all over again. However, I realized that I really don't need 3/4s of them anyway. If you're debating on this, and you are having issues with your current tablet  go for the iPad Mini, you will not regret it.

I finally broke down and bought the IPad mini with retina display.  I found a great deal on Amazon from an outside seller who was selling one they hardly ever used.  The price was so low that I couldn't resist.  It is my first experience with an IPad and I was curious.  I have the Samsung Tab S, the Tab Pro, and the Galaxy Tab 4 and I love them.  I have been using the Samsung phones and tablets since they first came out.  I am a big fan of android so I was a little apprehensive about using the Apple OS.  My IPad arrived in 2 days and is in pristine condition, in the original box with the original charger.  I really think I got an excellent deal from an excellent seller.  I was impressed with the fact that the seller put up photos of the IPad so I could actually see it before buying it.  I've been using it for a few days now and feel that I can give an objective review.  The initial set up took longer than setting up the Samsung tablets, but it was not difficult.  The retina display is very nice, but not as sharp as the Amoled display on the Tab S.  The IPad is quite a bit slower than the Samsung tablets.  The app store is not as good as the play store.  Installing apps is much slower and having to enter my password every time I open an app is a big pain in the neck.  Another huge difference is that there is no back button on the IPad and I really miss it!  Manuevering around the IPad with no back button is clumsy and frustrating.  Searching on the Web also takes longer than with android.  I think that the IPad is in so many ways out dated.  The build quality, although nice, I think the metal back will easily scratch, and it is much heavier than the Samsung tablets.  The screen of the IPad picks up finger prints and smudges much more than the Samsung.  The feel of the IPad is slippery and harder to grip too, whereas the grip of the Samsung tabs, although plastic, is much better.  All in all I like the Samsung tabs better.  They offer many more qualities than the IPad mini.  Their technology is much better and they are smarter and easier to use.  I was also disappointed in Siri, it seems that no matter what I asked, it could not answer, I prefer asking Google!  The battery life on both the IPad and Samsung is about the same, the IPad lasted just a bit longer, and charging was slower on the IPad by about an hour.  The Samsung take about 3 hours to charge fully and the IPad takes about 4 to 41/2 hours.  I am glad that I bought the IPad mini to experience it, and I now know how happy I am with my Samsung tablets.  So in conclusion, I recommend the IPad mini with retina display hesitantly.  For those who love Apple they will probably like it and for those who have not experienced the IPad I would recommend the Samsung tablets.

I've had the full sized Apple iPad with Retina Display for about a year and a half and have found that both my wife and I use it so frequently that getting a second iPad made sense. Plus, I got a great deal at B*st B*y and that was all it took to convince me to purchase this iPad mini. I selected the iPad mini version this time because I felt that the smaller size would be nice, and with the retina display I knew that the display quality would be excellent. It is also quite a bit less expensive (than the full size iPad) and for an impulse buy, that helps. Briefly stated this is a superb small tablet. If you are already invested in the Apple ecosystem then the apps you already own will load right up and it operates identically to your other devices. I'm not going to try to make the case for the Apple devices vs. Android tablets. I think they are both good, and both have their advantages and disadvantages. I've been using an iPhone for several years, as well as the larger iPad, so staying with Apple is a big advantage for me. That is what they want, of course, but it is also fine with me because I love the products. Pros: - The size and weight of this device is wonderful - this iPad mini is less than 50% of the weight of my full size iPad, which is a huge difference. The difference in weight is enough to make it much more comfortable to hold for any extended period. - The display is still large enough to web surf and read documents comfortably. It has the same display resolution as my full size iPad (2048-by-1536), with a higher 326 pixels per inch pixel density than the larger model. In other words, the two displays will show the same identical content, the mini simply a smaller version. The display is just crystal clear and sharp. - It comes with a charger and USB cable, which are all you need to get started. - It's compatible with all other Apple iPhone, iPod, iPad apps, works seamlessly with my iMac computer, and is easy to set up right out of the box. Cons: - the smaller display is of course slightly less suitable, compared to the full size iPad, for doing some things such as watching video. The speakers are also smaller and do not project the same volume of sound as the larger iPad. - as with all Apple products, not cheap Comments: - The 16GB size is the most affordable and is what I selected. It does mean that you are limited in what can be loaded on to the iPad. Many users, those who have large numbers of apps or keep many photos or music or video files on their device, will want the 32GB or even 64GB sizes. My needs are more modest. I use it more for streaming and web surfing, and other less memory intensive applications. The 16GB is therefore very sufficient for me, but it is at the low extreme for devices of this type today. I realize and accept that it may eventually limit me in what I can do with the device, that it means less ability to grow and for future needs. - Physically, this iPad mini is just slightly larger than Amazon's Kindle Fire HDX 7", HDX Display. The iPad display is somewhat larger than the 1920x1200 pixel Kindle display. The iPad is about half an inch taller, quarter of an inch wider, and is slightly thinner. They are just about the same weight. The iPad mini was just fifty dollars more expensive than the Kindle at the sale price I paid. The Kindle HDX would have been my alternate choice - I like Amazon's Kindle products, but again there is the issue of app compatibility with other iOS devices I already own. And the iPad works just fine in reading the books that I have in my Kindle library, using the Kindle app that I have installed. This is the wi-fi only version. My needs are only for a device for use at home and I have no desire or need to use this away from wi-fi networks or on my phone data plan. When the iPad mini was first introduced, my wife and I looked at one at the Apple store, and we had mixed feelings about whether or not we'd want the smaller size. And that was the original mini, before it had the retina display. Now that the mini has the retina display, and I have one myself and I've used it for several weeks, I'm not at all dissatisfied with the size. In fact, it has become the iPad that I use every day, while my wife continues to use the larger iPad (which she does prefer, but she also has not had much opportunity to use the mini because I've pretty much monopolized it). For a two-iPad family I think that having one of each size is a good way to go. For my purposes this is perfect.

Just purchased this because I'm a pilot and we all get our charts on Ipads these days. I already own a Google Nexus 7 tablet and was pretty happy with it, but developers of aviation apps have been slow to write apps for Android. Since I'm an instructor and most of my students use Ipads, I decided to get one so I could teach students how to use the aviation apps.

SURPRISE! I should have done more homework...the wifi only version doesn't include a GPS! It doesn't say that in the text. So, to use my Ipad in the car or cockpit, I had to spend $90 on a DUAL XGPS150 bluetooth GPS and always carry it along. All of the Google Nexus 7's include the GPS. Lame.

Also surprising: It's heavier, bigger, and costs over twice as much as the Google Nexus 7. The Ipad may be "mini," but it doesn't fit in the hand for reading as nicely as the Nexus 7. End result is, I'll continue to use the Nexus 7 for everything at home, and lug this sucker to the airplane with the external GPS for aviation. I feel like I wasted a lot of money on an inferior product. If I could do it over again (no returns if opened), I'd have gotten the 4G version for $175 more....but of course, the product description would have needed to tell me this one doesn't have GPS, which it didn't.

Overall, I'm very disappointed. Show me the value here...there is none. Don't pay the Apple Premium!

If I didn't have an ipad I probably would have gone for the current ipad 4(?) with a larger memory and retina display as the prices are comparable to the mini.  But having both is a lovely luxury.
P.S. I also had enough credit card "points" to pay for more than 2/3 the price --- which helped make the decision.

When getting ready to retire my BB Playbook.  Started looking at tablets.  Didn't want google, have served ties with that company as much as possible in this digital age.  Didn't like the current windows tablets.  So that left the Apple Ipad Mini.  Did not disappoint.

From where I stand, or sit, if you can get by the price of this 'cool standard', it's exactly what works for me because 1) the Mini comfortably fits in my palm, 2) the black model doesn't show dirt, 3) retina screen is out-of-control sharp and absolutely worth the extra 'blah-blah' than the original non-retina Mini; 4) AT&T flexibility for worldwide connectivity if I ever need it; 5) can use it as 'wifi only' without adding any plan until I need mobile/cellular (tomto/tomato) service and 6) with camera and video resolutions becoming greater and greater and as we have more photo, video and audio tools/apps at our disposal comes the need for more storage, hence the larger 64GB drive on this model, which will fill up quicker than you might think. So, yes the price jumps up quickly from the 16GB entry wifi-only model. But it is a Grand Slam of technology coupled with power, portability and fun (iTunes the App Store and more). A final note: This device should not be considered a laptop replacement. Most tablets don't come close. iPads (and most tablets) do not have any ports to plug things in such as drives, monitors, printers, keyboards, mice, optical drives, etc. Further, there is no file browser and it goes deeper. Yes there is Bluetooth connectivity that allows device daisy chains but then we start creatively architecting when all you really want is easy plug-and-play. So please consider your needs and usage carefully when you choose your tools :)

Actually, I liked this tablet better than I thought I would. However, as you will see below I have some major gripes with the price/features combination for this model. Lately I have been seriously thinking about upgrading my iPad 3. Tried the new Samsung Tab 10.1 (2014), iPad Air, and this Mini. Neither one of those larger tables really tempted me to give up on my iPad 3. Yes, they were a bit better in this and in that, but eventually neither one felt twice as good as my iPad 3 to justify their price (I figured that I would have to double the $280 or so that would get after selling my iPad 3).

iPad Mini retina did feel like a major upgrade in terms of size and weight. In fact, it is a better value in terms of size/weight vs screen size against iPad 3: you are dropping 50% of the weight and only losing 33% of the screen real estate (and nothing in resolution, of course). Surprisingly, most of the time I did not even feel any limitations of the smaller screen. I think part of the reason that made me like the new iPad Mini was that lately I have got a MBPr and the need for a larger retina screen now is satisfied by the laptop while the compactness of the tablet becomes more important.

However, there are two main problems that I have with the new Mini. One, is the limited gamut of the screen. I might be picky, but I do see the difference and not only side by side, but also when moving from one device to another. The larger iPad's home screen looks simply gorgeous in comparison to the Mini's home screen. (Probably, part of the reason is that I kept iOS 6 on my iPad 3 and it's color scheme is less "whitish.")

Another problem is pricing. How come after all these years of upgrading its larger tablets without increasing the price Apple decided to do it differently with the iPad Mini? The "original" iPad Mini was $330 and the iPad Mini retina is $400? Yes, the Mini got better, but the Air got better too with no price increase, same thing with iPad 4, iPad 3, and iPad 2. If they kept the price at $330 I would overlook the bleaker screen and go for it. Or if the screen had 100% gamut I would pay $400. But not both. I can not justify paying that much money while not feeling that I am getting a premium product. There are way cheaper tablets out there with 100% gamut and I do not want to pay $400 for a tablet and feel that it is inferior to a $220 tablet when it comes to such an important parameter as its screen.

You can see how much fewer reviews of this tablet are out there on amazon compared to the iPad Air. Seems like people are just not buying this model as much. I am returning the Mini and waiting until Apple comes up with an upgraded model that has 100% gamut screen. And they better not add another $70-$100 chunk on the top of the price when it happens!
